docs_intro: In this part of the website, you’ll find relevant information about it, along with more detailed content on Stoic philosophy, its most prominent figures, its key concepts, and a short guide to help the reader internalize Stoicism.
docs_faqs_desc: Frequently asked questions about the website.
docs_great_stoics_desc: A mention of the most influential Stoics of this philosophy and a brief description of the lives they lived.
docs_how_to_be_stoic_desc: A short guide to help the reader integrate certain Stoic habits into their daily life to gradually align with the quotes shown.
docs_key_concepts_desc: A glossary of the most useful and commonly used concepts and terms in the Stoic context—most of them in Latin or Greek.
docs_this_project_desc: Information about the development of this project, the technologies used, and a link to the GitHub repository.
faqs_q1_answer: On this website, a **different Stoic quote** will be shown every day along with its explanation/conclusion. The goal is to make this philosophy easier to understand and to inspire and motivate visitors through these quotes.
faqs_q2_question: What is the purpose of this website?
faqs_q2_answer: To spread and promote the values and principles of Stoicism. In today's society, a large part of the population (especially younger generations) rejects inherited religion. The rejection of old religions leaves a huge void in human morality and spirituality. At StoicQuote, we believe Stoicism can provide the missing piece—helping people become more whole while freeing them from the negative traits of the religion they inherited.
faqs_q3_question: Is AI used to generate the website's content?
faqs_q3_answer: No. Everything presented on the website is created entirely by the StoicQuote team. The quotes are taken from different books and texts (see the references), and the context and explanation/conclusion are written by the StoicQuote team to make the quote easier to understand and internalize.
faqs_q4_question: Are the quotes exclusively from Stoic philosophers?
faqs_q4_answer: No. The authors range from historical figures to modern public personalities, including certain philosophers or scientists who **have never identified as Stoics**, but whose quotes fit Stoic philosophy perfectly.
faqs_q5_answer: You can contribute by making a [donation](www.paypal.com) to help maintain the website, or by emailing us a quote (with its reference) that you think matches Stoic philosophy at stoicquotejos@gmail.com.
faqs_q6_question: Why keep promoting Stoicism if everyone already knows what it is?
faqs_q6_answer: Many people picture Stoics as serious guys in robes with beards, staring at the horizon while dropping minimalist tattoo-worthy quotes. Reality is less Instagram-friendly: they were **ordinary people**, with ordinary problems,\nwho developed *extremely useful mental tools* to avoid going crazy.
how_to_be_stoic_intro: A small guide to becoming a bit more stoic each day, without falling into the false dichotomy fallacy: you can’t be “not stoic” and wake up the next day as the embodiment of Marcus Aurelius; it’s a matter of habits and self-learning.
how_to_be_stoic_habit_1: Write down a negative comment you receive—or something that disturbs you during the day. Reflect on whether it truly affects your inner peace unnecessarily. Learn to separate useful criticism from harmful criticism.
how_to_be_stoic_habit_2: During the day, identify an impulse (anger, speaking without thinking, actions you wouldn’t choose if you reflected calmly). Pause for five seconds before acting. Reflect on your reaction.
how_to_be_stoic_habit_3: Before you start the day, do you stop to think—or do you only react? Taking a few minutes to think, without distractions, can give you more clarity, calm, and direction than any external stimulus. Don’t let social media steer your life; steer it consciously and actively.
how_to_be_stoic_habit_4: Self-observation is crucial for personal growth. We all make mistakes; we can all improve—but without self-observation and self-critique, we won’t be able to. Try to observe yourself daily as if you were a third person.
how_to_be_stoic_habit_5: Visualizing adversity is an exercise promoted by several of the greatest Stoics. They asked themselves questions like: What can I do if this happens? What part of this event is under my control (the dichotomy of control)? Why is this event natural and inevitable?
how_to_be_stoic_marcus_quote:
> In the morning, tell yourself: Today I will meet an intrusive, ungrateful, arrogant, deceitful, envious, and unsocial person. All these things have happened to them because they do not know what is truly good and bad. But I, who understand the nature of the good—that it is worthy of desire—and of the bad—that it is truly shameful—also know that the wrongdoer is my relative, not by blood, but by sharing the same reason and a portion of the divine. How could I be harmed by any of them, since it is not in their power to make me do anything truly blameworthy or to make me angry and hostile toward someone who is naturally close to me? For we are born to work together.
>
> — Marcus Aurelius
how_to_be_stoic_pigliucci_note: Pigliucci called this Stoic exercise *premeditatio malorum*.
how_to_be_stoic_q1: When a thought disturbs you, apply the famous dichotomy of control: Is there anything I can do to control the fact that’s bothering me? If not, it isn’t worth worrying about. Then practice amor fati: love your fate and accept what happens.
how_to_be_stoic_q2: How much does this really matter in the context of my whole life?
how_to_be_stoic_kahneman_quote:
> Nothing is as serious as it seems when you think about it.
>
> — Daniel Kahneman
how_to_be_stoic_q3: What can I be grateful for today? If you think coldly and make an effort to value the life you have, you’ll find deep satisfaction in the life you’re living. Many Stoics insist on appreciating small things. This isn’t about being hedonistic—quite the opposite. It’s about valuing as much as possible what you already possess and avoiding excessive desire, because that tends to create near-chronic dissatisfaction. Be grateful for having two working legs and arms, for never going hungry, for hot showers, and even for the pleasure of feeling the sun on your skin every day.
how_to_be_stoic_cato_quote:
> Try to convince yourself that death should not be feared: if it is not a good, it is at least the end of all evils.
>
> — Cato the Younger
how_to_be_stoic_mindset_title: The Right Mindset for a Stoic Life
how_to_be_stoic_mindset_body: Being Stoic isn’t about “feeling less.” It’s about thinking better, choosing better, and building a character that doesn’t depend on luck and avoids victimhood. It’s not about winning every inner battle; it’s about **not surrendering to the first impression** and training your mind the way you train your body—little by little, every day.
key_concepts_intro: Across various Stoic texts, we can find certain concepts—often expressed in Latin or Greek—that define ideas far more precisely than a long explanation would. This section presents the ones most commonly mentioned.
key_concepts_1_body: Eudaimonia is the ultimate aim in Stoicism, understood as achieving an active life grounded in **virtue** (_aretē_) and **reason**—which implies being diligent, pursuing continuous progress, and living with purpose. It is the **activity of the soul in accordance with virtue** across a complete life.
key_concepts_2_body: It is defined as the **total absence of anguish and fear**, resulting in a state of balance and mental calm. Ataraxia is not a primary end, but rather a **consequence** of living a virtuous and disciplined life. It is pursued by restraining excessive desires and external stimuli that trigger irrational disturbance. In other words, true serenity arises when discipline enables us to quiet fear and irrational anxiety.
key_concepts_3_body: **Askēsis** refers to the **constant and deliberate practice and training of the mind and character**. Its purpose is to develop virtue and self-control. This concept includes voluntary exposure to discomfort to strengthen resilience, self-examination, and iron discipline. In other words, a virtuous character is not innate—it must be forged through sustained effort and chosen discomfort.
key_concepts_4_body: It means **accepting—and loving—fate**, or whatever the course of events brings, without fighting what is inevitable. This principle is closely tied to the **Dichotomy of Control**, which advises focusing effort only on what lies within our power. In other words, by loving everything that happens—the good and the bad—we remove inner resistance and find peace in what we cannot control.
key_concepts_5_body: It is the mental practice of **visualizing and contemplating the worst possible scenarios** or adversities. Promoted by Seneca, this technique aims to increase resilience by facing fears in advance, preparing the mind to meet real events with greater temperance. In other words, by becoming familiar with adversity in our mind, we reduce the emotional _shock_ when it appears in reality.
key_concepts_6_body: **Apatheia** is the state in which one learns to control and neutralize **irrational and destructive passions** (_pathos_). It is the mental ideal that enables action guided exclusively by **reason** and common sense, remaining steady in the face of uncontrolled emotional influences. In other words, the model Stoic acts from clear judgment and rationality, free from the tyranny of impulses and runaway emotions.

the_great_stoics_zenon_body:
The founder of Stoicism. Zeno didn’t invent Stoicism out of thin air—he was a “curator” of ideas. He studied with the **Cynics** (from whom he inherited the importance of virtue and contempt for unnecessary social conventions), with the Megarians, and with the Academics. Zeno began teaching in a public colonnade decorated with paintings in Athens, called the **Stoa Poikile** (Painted Porch). Unlike other schools that were private or exclusive, Zeno’s was open to anyone passing by. The name of the philosophy comes from “Stoa”.

Zeno laid the foundations of the three Stoic pillars:

- **Logic**: *How we process information.*
- **Physics**: *How the world works (the Logos).*
- **Ethics**: *How we should live (living in accordance with nature).*

>Nobody should feel any loss more keenly than the loss of time, because it is irreparable.
>– Zeno of Citium
the_great_stoics_cleanthes_body:
Cleanthes, often described as the formal founder of Stoicism, is said to have been a **boxer** who arrived in Athens with very few resources and, in order to study philosophy with Zeno during the day, worked at night drawing water from gardens (earning him the nickname “the water carrier”).

Cleanthes added a layer of religious and spiritual depth to Stoicism. His famous **“Hymn to Zeus”** is cited as a key piece in which the universe is understood as an ordered and harmonious whole under a universal reason (_Logos_). Cleanthes saw virtue not only as something practical, but as a way of aligning with the divine nature of the cosmos.

Cleanthes’ example shows that Stoic philosophy is not for “armchair intellectuals,” but for people willing to get their hands dirty. His ability to study after exhausting days of physical labor is presented as proof that will can overcome any external circumstance.

>Fate leads the willing and drags the unwilling.
>– Cleanthes of Assos
the_great_stoics_chrysippus_body:
While Zeno founded the school and Cleanthes kept it alive, it was Chrysippus who gave it its definitive intellectual structure. He is credited with developing much of **propositional logic**, which is the basis for how the Stoics analyzed reality and language. Chrysippus is largely responsible for Stoicism being more than a set of “moral tips,” turning it into a robust philosophy grounded in reason and physics.

A quick mind—sometimes arrogant because of his intellect—but deeply devoted to truth.

>If I knew that my fate was to fall ill, I would even wish for it; for even the foot, if it had intelligence, would volunteer to step into the mud.
>– Chrysippus of Soli
the_great_stoics_cato_title: Marcus Porcius Cato. cato The Younger (95 BC – 46 BC)
the_great_stoics_cato_body:
We could present **Marcus Porcius Cato**, known as **Cato the Younger**, not only as a philosopher, but as the **ultimate model of integrity and ethical resistance** in the Roman world. For George Washington and revolutionary America, Cato the Younger represented Liberty with a capital L. The most persuasive exception—principled to the core—to the rule against self-sacrifice. For Julius Caesar, the dictator famous for pardoning his opponents, Marcus Porcius Cato was the one man he could never forgive. A moral lighthouse, he consistently condemned and pointed to the growing corruption around him.

Cato symbolizes the fight for principles even when the battle is lost, reminding us that the Stoic does not necessarily seek external success, but to act correctly according to reason. Cato preferred defeat and death with integrity over victory bought by sacrificing values. He became the reference point for later Roman Stoics, like Seneca or Marcus Aurelius.

Cato the Younger is the definitive example of “Askēsis”.

>This is no time for vacation and recreation; we must restrain this man or die honorably contending for freedom.
>– Cato the Younger
the_great_stoics_seneca_body:
Seneca was a philosopher who preached austerity while being one of the richest men in Rome and advisor to a tyrannical emperor like Nero. Seneca wasn’t a perfect “sage,” but a practitioner in progress (_proficiens_) who constantly struggled to align his actions with his ideas. He is the author who best translated Greek Stoicism into Roman pragmatism, focusing on everyday themes like anger, grief, the brevity of life, and friendship. For many, his _Letters to Lucilius_ are the definitive manual of Stoic “psychotherapy.”

Seneca, with a certain obsession with the use of time, is known for the idea that life isn’t short—we waste it on trivialities. He is also credited with giving major momentum to **Premeditatio Malorum**.

Forced by Nero to take his own life, Seneca faced death with astonishing calm, consoling his friends and remaining faithful to his Stoic principles to the very end.

>A king is one who fears nothing; a king is one who desires nothing; and all of us can give ourselves that kingdom.
>– Seneca
the_great_stoics_epictetus_body:
The most pragmatic, direct, and “sharp” voice in the entire school. His story is probably the one that best captures Stoicism’s power to free the human mind. He was born a slave in Hierapolis and lived much of his life in Rome serving a master (who, according to legend, broke his leg, leaving him lame for life).

Epictetus is the supreme example that **freedom is not a physical condition, but a state of mind**. Despite his chains, he considered himself freer than his master because he owned his judgments. His teaching always begins with the fundamental distinction: there are things that depend on us (our thoughts, desires, and actions) and things that do not (the body, wealth, reputation, or what others think).

Epictetus strongly defended **_Prohairesis_**, the moral faculty: our ability to decide how to interpret what happens to us.

One of his most famous metaphors: life is like a play where we don’t choose our role (you might be the king or the beggar), but our only mission is to **play that role as well as possible**. Excellence is not in the position, but in the performance.

>Freedom is the only worthy goal in life. It is won by ignoring things that are beyond our control.
>– Epictetus
the_great_stoics_marcus_aurelius_body:
The man who held all the power of the known world and still chose humility and self-discipline. An intellectually inclined and peaceful man who was forced to rule the Roman Empire during one of its darkest periods (plagues, constant frontier wars, and betrayals). For many, Marcus Aurelius is the highest example of **doing one’s duty** (_Eusebeia_) above personal desires.

His work, the _Meditations_, was not written to be published. It was a personal journal, an exercise in **self-examination**, and a reminder of his own Stoic principles.

Marcus Aurelius understood that even if the empire was in chaos, his mind could remain like an unbreakable fortress (the Inner Citadel). This metaphor shows how Stoicism allowed him to keep calm and just while making decisions affecting millions. He often imagined viewing Earth from the stars to see how insignificant his problems and human conflicts were compared to the immensity of time and space. He was deeply aware of **Memento Mori** (remember that you will die). He reflected on how even the most famous emperors end up forgotten, which helped him focus only on what matters: acting with justice and reason in the present.

>Pain can never be unbearable or of long duration, unless you magnify it with imagination; you must see it within its natural limits.
>– Marcus Aurelius
the_great_stoics_musonius_rufus_body:
Musonius Rufus was Epictetus’ mentor; without Musonius’ influence, we wouldn’t fully understand Epictetus’ toughness and pragmatism. A teacher with moral authority, capable of drawing the brightest minds of Rome toward a life of absolute discipline. He believed theory was useless if it didn’t heal vices and strengthen character. He insisted philosophy is a **practical tool for daily life**, focused on ethical action rather than complex speeches.

Musonius’ “revolutionary” character for his time stands out. He firmly defended that women should receive the same philosophical education as men, arguing that both possess the same rational capacity and the same need to develop virtue in order to live well.

Musonius Rufus was extremely strict about **discipline of the body**. His teachings on food also stand out (preferring simple, natural foods) and on lifestyle, arguing that luxury corrupts the soul. For him, physical and mental training were inseparable from _Askēsis_.

Like Seneca, he suffered exile for political reasons (on several occasions). He used his time on the island of Gyaros to cultivate the land and teach philosophy, showing that a Stoic can flourish in any circumstance, no matter how hostile.

>If you achieve something good through hard work, the effort passes quickly, but the good endures.
>– Gaius Musonius Rufus
